text: the hedonistic Paradox is something that
ancient philosophers uh were aware of uh
when they pointed out that people who
directly aim at pleasure that's where
the term Hedonism comes from people who
directly aim at pleasure seldom get it
um they end up finding the things that
they thought would give them pleasure
not satisfying not pleasing to them on
the other hand people who don't aim at
pleasure but aim at something else some
activity that's worthwhile in itself and
they get absorbed in the moment of doing
what they're doing have what psychology
called flow um they actually get
enjoyment and fulfillment out of it so
the Paradox of Hedonism is if you want
to get more satisfaction more more
happiness out of life don't aim for
happiness aim for something else I the
Paradox of Hedonism uh in response to
questions like uh well why should I be
why should I be moral why should I
pursue morality why shouldn't I just go
after my own happiness why shouldn't I
earn what money I can and then retire to
the beach where I'll have you know uh
Beautiful People of the other sex uh
rubbing oil into my skin or whatever um
you know whatever your vision of of
Hedonism might be um
uh and uh so what I argue is that that's
really not likely to bring you happiness
and you're more likely to get happiness
from doing something that's
intrinsically worthwhile that you can
see as worthwhile and you can take some
real satisfaction from when you actually
succeed in achieving it
[Music]
